# Technique

![Scour Test @maslowskiDiagnosticValidityHip2010](/The Archive/Examination/Tests and Measures/Lower extremity tests/Hip Tests/images/maslowskiDiagnosticValidityHip2010 fig3 scour test.png)

|Quadrant|Position|
|-|-|
|Inner Quadrant|90&deg; Flexion + Max Adduction|
|Outer Quadrant|90&deg; Flexion + Max Abduction|
: {.striped}

- Supine
    - Position the patient at the lateral edge of bed on testing side
- Passively bring the hip into 90&deg; Hip flexion and ~90&deg; knee flexion @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
- Inner Quadrant
    - Passively adduct the hip to end range (when the pelvis lifts off the bed) @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
    - Apply a compression along the longitudinal axis of the femur
- Outer quadrant
    - Bring the femur into 90&deg; Flexion and Max hip abduction @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
    - Apply a compression force along the longitudinal axis of the femur


Abnormal findings:

- Apprehension
- Resistance
- [Pain](#provocation) @maslowskiDiagnosticValidityHip2010
- Crepitus

# Provocation Finding {#provocation}

Provocation of pain is considered a positive test.
Pain can result from compression or stress to a number of structures:

- Articular surfaces of the femoroacetabular joint @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
- Acetabular labrum @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
- Hip joint capsule @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
- Muscular compression
    - TFL origin @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
    - Sartorius origin @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
    - Iliopsoas muscle @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
    - Pectineus muscle @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
    - Adductor longus @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
- Internal pudendal bundle (IPB) and neurovascular bundle @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
- Femoral neck
